Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 04:24PM BrilandGirl wrote: Hello to everyone--I finished Week 1 of radiation on Friday.  Fairly easy so far but feeling a bit tired.  Really don't want to mess up the skin--breast is already messed up with 2 biopsy scars, lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy scars.  Nurse says to use aloe and corn starch only for now but I'm hesitant to wait until I have problems.  Therefore, I'm using Lily of the Desert aloe (the Fruit of the Earth sample from doctor's office has a couple of unhealthy additives--possible carcinogen and another ingredient that may release formaldehyde) and Boiron Calendula Cream (10%).  Hopefully, this will keep the skin happy and trouble-free.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 04:52PM - edited Jan 30, 2011 04:53PM by BrilandGirl Thanks, Jo, for the welcome.  And Omaz--yes, the fresh aloe would be the best way.  May just be a bit watery since aloe gels contain thickeners.  I'm just learning about some of the cosmetic ingredients that are not so good for us--don't know if there's enough of these ingredients to make a real difference but I figure why take that chance if there are alternatives available.  This will be a long road but I'm grateful for all my friends, family, doctors and health insurance!

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 03:00PM BrilandGirl wrote: JoAnn:  I use the Lily of the Desert Aloe Gelly and the Boiron Calendula Cream--it's 2.5 oz. and about $10 at Whole Foods.  It has the highest concentration of calendula at 10% (ointment is 4%).  Plus it's not greasy and the ointment is in a petrolatum base (Vaseline).  Also, plain corn starch is good to use on underarm and under the breast.   Saturn:  Congrats on finishing--I have 5 more boosts left.  I also had good results with the aloe and Boiron.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 02:51PM BrilandGirl wrote: I don't think it's that unusual.  My first biopsy was a month from the mammogram where they spotted the cluster of calcification spots.  I had to reschedule it so it was 6 weeks out.   Then I actually needed a second biopsy so it took about 10 or 11 weeks from the original mammogram to the second biopsy and then another 3-1/2 weeks to the surgery.  Even with the 3-1/2 months from detection to surgery, my tumor was only 2mm.  I've read that most breast cancers take years to grow so I don't think a month or two makes a big difference.  However, the inflammatory kind grows faster but I don't know the timing--and there are specific symptoms for inflammatory kind. Also bear in mind that in the majority of the cases (think 80%), it's benign.  However, I know that it can be an anxious time--and early detection is key.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: how long to wait for a biopsy mudd BrilandGirl

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 12:31PM BrilandGirl wrote: Kerry:  Congratulations on all your success!  I love your story and have this posted as a Favorite Topic--just like the moderator stated.  I used to jog years ago and have started walking by the beach--and will add swimming lessons and return to yoga and meditation. Claire in Seattle:  Thank you for letting me know about Kerrymac--I am going to use her as another role model to get healthy and strong so I can truly be my alter ego--Kim Strong.  I may even take a self-defense class to get as strong as possible so I will never feel helpless or weak---my best life is ahead!
Posts.Title: I am what a Cancer Survivor looks like! KerryMac Heidihill

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 06:43PM - edited Feb 20, 2011 06:54PM by BrilandGirl Another important factor is the doctor who is analyzing the mammogram image.  I also have dense breast tissue but the radiologist picked up a tiny cluster of calcification spots on my routine mammogram--also I had a digital mammogram which is better for dense tissue. My surgeon said that many places would not have even picked it up.  My IDC tumor turned out to be only 2mm.  Another fortunate step in my early dectection was that my biopsy radiologist suggested that I repeat the procedure.  My first biopsy results were benign--however, the doctor wanted to review the results over the weekend.  She called me Monday morning and told me she was not satifsfiied with the number of samplings and suggested that I come in for a second biopsy (at no charge).  The second biopsy was painful as I hadn't healed from the first one but worth it--it picked up the invasive cancer cells (along with some DCIS).  Then my surgeon ordered the MRI for better imaging prior to the surgery.  I'm fortunate to have good doctors who are thorough and I feel like a poster child for early detection.  As a first step, make sure that the doctors who are reading the mammograms have lots of experience and try to go to a place that has a digital machine if you have dense breast tissue.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 09:54PM - edited Feb 14, 2011 10:03PM by BrilandGirl Amyjo49:  parabens (methylparaben,propylparaben, ethyparaben, butylparaben) are preservatives that mimic estrogen, which can stimulate breast cancer cells.  I read that parabens have been banned in Europe (must be why the Boiron calendula cream was reformulated).  My skin care instruction sheet from my RO's office: Hope this helps.  I got my RO's approval to use the calendula cream (Boiron)  Other things I've heard/read is not to use oils which may not wash off completely and intensifies the radiation effects (however, I've read that some swear by emu oil so different strokes for different folks).   I would stay away from fragranced products on the breast being treated--I used one calendula cream with added fragrance and it stung.  I'm also avoiding bras most of the time--using camisoles or sometimes a soft front-closing one--trying to avoid putting pressure on skin.  Now time for my aloe gel and calendula cream! Kim from NY
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 01:11PM BrilandGirl wrote: My stereotactic vacuum assisted needle core biopsy (I think that was the complete description) procedure took about 45 minutes.  There was paperwork, some waiting and a mammogram afterwards.  Not sure if your procedure is the same but you may be a bit sore afterwards so I would try to get someone to go with you.  Also, you're not supposed to use the affected side too much for the following 24 hours and no aspirin products--just Tylenol for the pain.  My procedure involved lidocaine, small incision for the needle and then a lot of noise from the big machine that was used to find the spots to remove.  My results were back the next afternoon as the office is close to a major hospital but I think each office is different for the timing of the results. The doctor should tell you before the biopsy about the timing.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: core biopsy mudd SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 12:50PM BrilandGirl wrote: I was also sore for a while and had a lot of bruising and then a gigantic hematoma after my lumpectomy in Nov '10.  I have a feeling that I overdid it (was shopping and driving two days after the surgery).  I dug up my post-op instructions and one of them is:  Please refrain from ANY exercise or heavy lifting until you are seen post-operatively.  This is extremely important to avoid excessive swelling or delayed healing.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 04:03PM BrilandGirl wrote: Had #24 out of 33 today--only 9 more left (2 more whole breast and 7 boosts).  RO said my skin is holding up "like average"--not better or worse than average condition given the number of treatments.  Seems silly but I felt disappointed--I thought my skin was holding up pretty well--it's a bid red and nothing else so far--spent hours reading up on skincare here and researching products!  Felt like I got a grade of C when I spent time and effort enough for an A.  Well--as long as my skin is holding up--that's what matters.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 09:22PM BrilandGirl wrote: I also had #15 out of 33 yesterday and my skin is pinkish--a bit red.  I can see the rectangle area of the color at this point but no peeling yet.  I've been using Lily of the Desert aloe gel, followed by Boiron Calendula Cream and RO thought my skin was doing well.  The Boiron cream contaned parabens (seems strange for a line of homeopathic products) so I am now using Indian Meadows Herbals Love Your Body Cream (found at Mrs. Greens store) which is infused with calendula flowers--the cream feels very soothing.  Also started using corn starch under arm and under the breast, which was on the instruction sheet.  I also switched to Basis bar soap as it's gentle and fragrance free.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 12:11AM BrilandGirl wrote: heathermcd:  The Boiron calendula cream  (2.6oz) I bought had methylparaben and propylparaben as the last two ingredients (listing is available on Amazon).  However, I just saw a box of the same cream at Whole Foods in NYC and no parabens were listed--I think they changed the formula.  Check your box for the ingredients--I just checked Boiron's website and no parabens there.  I think I got one from the old batch when I bought mine at a small local pharmacy.  I've finished off my first tube and may get a tube of the new formula.  Looks like calendula is included in a number of products for radiation creams--along with aloe--so I'm using both several times a day.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2011 04:00PM BrilandGirl wrote: Happy to report I'm done with 31 out of 33 sessions--only 2 more boosts left. Rad graduation is Wednesday. No skin breakdown at all so far--just a square tan. Basis unscented bar soap, Lily of Desert aloe gelly and Boiron calendula cream with dusting of corn starch have worked well for me. Didn't wear bra most of the time--any pressure on skin was painful. Also took time to air out the breast in evenings.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 06:40PM BrilandGirl wrote: Beacher:  Sorry to hear about your skin.  I read that you're using four different creams/lotions and always keep it moist.  I would try reducing the number of products--maybe just the aloe and the Miaderm, which was formulated just for radiation and seems to contain everything needed.  The Andra Sina lotion and the Aquaphor both contain oils are more general purpose products--also the Andra Sina contain parabens, which I've read is now banned in Europe.  Also, I would try to air out the skin a bit--I let my aloe and calendula cream soak in, put some corn starch underarm and under the breast before going to bed and let the skin dry for half hour or so.  My RO also said to hold out my arm away from my body as well for a bit to lessen the skin to skin contact. Grannydukes:  The radiation effect continues in your body for two weeks after the last treatment.  The emu oil sounds great from some of the posts I've read here but I'd be a little worried about the oil intensifying the radiation burning effect.  I used a calendula infused cream that had almond and sunflower oil--felt good going on but then felt my skin get warmer and a bunch of little red spots appeared.  So I just use aloe and then Boiron calendula cream that doesn't contain oils Completed #19 out of 33 today. So far, so good and I really hope my skins holds up for the next half. Doctor also marked my skin for boosts--don't know why so early--boosts start with session 27.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 05:03PM BrilandGirl wrote: Beacher:  congrats on finishing--I also finished today--#33 done.  Received a "certificate" and a box with a stuffed animal, paperbook, cards, etc. donated by a local store--very nice of the store and staff. Heathermcd:  I hope your skin heals soon--I had no real skin issues except today--when they peeled off one of the stickers, they peeled off some of the skin--ouch!  Even this small area of peeling hurts so your pain must be awful.  They gave me a tube of bacitracin zinc ointment. AmyJo:  Glad to hear that your skin is doing well--good luck with the second half!   To anyone who gets any tape (I had three for my boost area--my magic marker kept washing off)--don't let the technician take it off--I forgot that the nurse had told me to keep it on and remove it later by using a lot of ointment underneath.  Good luck to everyone--Kim
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 07:33PM BrilandGirl wrote: My doctors also told me not to worry about my cluster of calcifications but in the end, I ended up in the unlucky 20%.  However, it was caught early during a routine mammogram (I'm 47) so my prognosis is very good.  Chances are good that yours will be benign--however, since you've been getting yearly mammograms, even if it turns out to be cancerous, it should be highly treatable.  So try to relax and spend time with people you enjoy.  Good luck.
